instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.GPUVCORE_EN: What is GPUVCORE_EN? GPUVCORE_EN enables GPU VCORE when it is high, a power rail necessary for the GPU to function so you can get an image on the screen. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No GPU Vcore
threads.message: It turns on and chimes, has good CPU Vcore, but no <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> (and it's not shorted to GND). Someone obviously messed with <CHIP>U9300</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q9330</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q9331</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q9361</TRANSISTOR> as <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> has no bond on the edges and all of these had flux residues around. I changed all of them, but it's still the same. <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> gets tiny pulse after turning on. Not even a pulse on <SIGNAL>PP5VR3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>. Nothing on external screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No GPU Vcore
threads.message:
This could be waste of time now.
That "someone else" (tehnician???) could already f***d off the board.

You can check basic voltages for <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> and look for knocked off components in that area.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R9330</RESISTOR>/60 and <CAPACITOR>C9330</CAPACITOR>/65 are good.
